thread.title: Jobless claims data show layoffs remain scarce - MarketWatch
thread.title_full: Jobless claims data show layoffs remain scarce - MarketWatch

author: Greg Robb
title: Jobless claims data show layoffs remain scarce - MarketWatch
text:
Getty Images A job seeker looks at job listings in Oakland, California. Initial claims for state unemployment benefits continued to hover near 40-year lows, according to the latest reading, a sign that layoffs in the economy remain scarce.
Jobless claims inched higher by 3,000 to 267,000 in the week ended Sept. 19, only partially reversing the sharp 17,000 decline over the prior two weeks, the Labor Department said Thursday.
This is the 29th straight week claims have come in under 300,000, an unofficial threshold of a firming labor market.
“Layoff activity is muted, simply put,” said Thomas Simons, money-market economist at Jefferies.
The report came out just before Caterpillar said it plans to shed 10,000 jobs by the end of 2018 as part of a restructuring program.
The four-week average slipped by 750 to 272,000. This is down from 283,000, on average for the first eight months of the year.
“Domestic strength is offsetting foreign weakness — something to keep in mind when interpreting the just-reported 2% decline in export-intensive durable goods orders [in August],” said Jim O’Sullivan, chief U.S. economist at High Frequency Economics.
Read more: Durable-goods orders fall for first time in 3 months
